title-group.article-title: What Is Special about the Roles of Underwriter Reputation and Market Activities in Initial Public Offerings?*

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2002 by The University of Chicago. All rights reserved.

abstract.p: This article examines the interaction between underwriter reputation and market activities during the initial public offering (IPO) process. Underwriter reputation is a significant determinant of premarket underwriter activities, weakly related to aftermarket price stabilization activities, and unrelated to issuer returns. Premarket underwriter activities are a significant determinant of issue‐date returns and aftermarket underwriter activities but are unrelated to longer‐run returns. Aftermarket underwriter activities are significantly related to longer‐run returns. The results suggest that simultaneous consideration of underwriter reputation and market activities is important if proper inferences about the IPO process and investor returns are to be drawn.

fn.p: We thank Rajesh Aggarwal, Reena Aggarwal, Jay Ritter, Seha Tinic, Bill Wilhelm, an anonymous referee, and seminar participants at Georgetown, Wisconsin, the 1999 FMA Conference, the 1999 FMA European Conference, and the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission for extensive comments on earlier drafts of this article. The article previously circulated under the title of “Underwriter Book‐Building Methods, Investment Bank Reputation, and the Return Performance of Firms Conducting Initial Public Offerings.”

sec.label: I.
sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: For reasons that are not yet entirely understood, sellers in the market for new shares of common equity often agree to set their initial public offering (IPO) prices at a level where there is excess demand and then ration offer size, rather than set market‐clearing prices. In order for rationing to be an effective selling mechanism, the seller must be able to precommit credibly to an offer price that compensates investors for their investigation and information‐gathering costs. One way a seller can do this is to develop a reputation for establishing fair prices and then transact in the aftermarket as a bonding mechanism. Since a firm typically goes public only once, however, issuers may be unable to use their own reputations and aftermarket bonding activities to sell shares efficiently. They typically rely on the underwriting services of an investment bank to market their IPOs.1

Investment banks provide a number of interrelated marketing, pricing, and distribution services for IPO issuers. These activities occur prior to the offer date (in the “premarket” period) and after the offer date (in the “aftermarket” period). Our study differs from prior empirical research by modeling investment bank activities as sequential, integrated elements of an underwriting process rather than as a series of unrelated, isolated decisions. Because the reputation of the investment bank may influence investors’ opinions about the quality of an issuer and its long‐term prospects, we also investigate the relationship between underwriter reputation and market activities, and their influence on short‐run and long‐run investor returns.

Several explanations of the roles of underpricing and rationing in the marketing of IPOs have been proposed in the literature. The first explanation suggests that high‐quality firms underprice their IPOs in order to signal private information about firm value to investors. High‐quality firms subsequently reap the signaling benefits by issuing seasoned equity in a follow‐on offering at more favorable prices (see, e.g., Allen and Faulhaber1989; Grinblatt and Hwang1989; and Welch1989).

A second explanation, as argued by Benveniste and Spindt (1989) and Benveniste, Busaba, and Wilhelm (1996), suggests that investors must be compensated for truthful revelation of their private information about the value of the issuing firm. Underpricing serves as a reward for truthful information revelation, and rationing allows the investment bank to distribute that reward selectively to informed investors.

A third explanation suggests that underpricing stimulates new share purchases in IPOs by absolving potential shareholders of the winner’s‐curse problem. Rationing and underpricing create more winners and so reduce the bad news learned by investors receiving allocations in an IPO (see, e.g., Rock1986; Bulow and Klemperer1999). This encourages uninformed investors to raise their bids for shares.

Finally, Brennan and Franks (1997) argue that since underpricing ensures oversubscription, issuers can ration post‐IPO ownership strategically through the share allocation process. Therefore, underpricing and rationing allow insiders to retain control after the IPO.2

Each of these explanations implies that premarket pricing adjustments, reputation, and aftermarket bonding activities are interrelated components of an integrated underwriter service. We present several pieces of evidence that clarify the distinctive roles of underwriter reputation and market activities in resolving information and control problems in IPOs. We use a methodology known as path analysis to measure the incremental contributions of an investment bank’s reputation and its various underwriting activities to investor returns. Such an approach allows us to analyze the effect of an underwriter’s reputation (which is presumably based upon previous successful marketing of IPOs) separately from the effect of the underwriter’s activities on the marketing of the current IPO.3

Our results indicate that simultaneous consideration of underwriter reputation and market activities is crucial if we are to draw proper inferences about the IPO process and investor returns. First, we find that premarket underwriter activities are the most significant determinant of new issue underpricing. This finding suggests that the underwriter’s pricing and share allocation decisions play an important role in determining the response of investors to the rationing equilibrium.

We also find that higher‐quality investment banks are more likely to adjust prices upward during the IPO process. This result establishes that underwriter reputation facilitates the conduct of premarket underwriter activities. We interpret this result as explaining why investment banks invest in reputation and why firms are willing to pay for the reputational service. Reputation is valuable because it helps generate more business (and hence higher fees) for an underwriter. Issuers are willing to pay for reputation, because reputation allows the underwriter to be effective in premarket activities. Issuers benefit from more efficient premarket activities through a cost‐effective resolution of information problems and retention of greater insider control.4

Second, we find no relationship between underwriter reputation and investor returns measured over several different holding‐period horizons. Contrary to the conventional wisdom, underwriter reputation has no direct effect on IPO returns. Instead, premarket underwriter activities are the most significant determinant of issue‐date returns. Investor returns in IPOs depend on the price and share allocation adjustment decisions of the underwriter, not the underwriter’s reputation per se. This finding differs from prior work that reports a negative relationship between underwriter reputation and issue‐date investor returns and a positive relationship between long‐run returns and underwriter reputation (see, e.g., Beatty and Ritter1986; Carter and Manaster1990; and Carter, Dark, and Singh1998).

Beatty and Welch (1996) and Cooney et al. (2000) also report changes in the relationship between underwriter reputation and issue‐date investor returns that are consistent with our findings. Beatty and Welch (1996) suggest that the change in the relationship between underwriter reputation and underpricing is most likely due to differences in economic conditions in the 1990s versus the 1980s. Cooney et al. (2000) attribute the difference to a significant increase in the number of high‐demand IPOs in which the final offer price is set above the upper estimated offer price filed with the preliminary prospectus.

Our results confirm these findings and indicate that there has been a significant change in the conduct of premarket underwriting activities by investment banks during the 1990s. We find, however, that the principal influence of underwriter reputation on issue‐date returns is not direct, but rather indirect, through their conduct of premarket underwriting activities.

Third, underwriter reputation is only modestly related to aftermarket underwriter activities. We find no relationship between underwriter reputation and the decision to exercise the overallotment option (OAO). The reputation of the underwriter is related to the conduct of price stabilization activities, so a second, although less compelling, motive for the use of underwriter reputation as a selection criterion in an IPO is the underwriter’s ability to conduct price stabilization activities. We attribute this weak result to the common IPO underwriting practice of using short positions in conjunction with the OAO as a price support mechanism rather than using stabilizing bids. The latter is potentially risky and capital‐intensive, while the former is not. Therefore, individual investment banks are unlikely to have specialized abilities that distinguish their conduct of aftermarket activities from that of other investment banks.5

Fourth, we find that aftermarket underwriter activities have a stronger relationship with investor returns over long‐run return horizons than does underwriter reputation, issue‐date pricing, or premarket underwriter activities. Price stabilization activities are particularly important for 3‐, 6‐, and 12‐month return horizons, while OAO exercise becomes more important over the 36‐month time period. The influence of the OAO exercise remains fairly constant throughout the different time horizons examined, while the influence of price stabilization activities declines as the time horizon lengthens. To the extent that OAO exercise proxies for excess investor demand, the results suggest that issues with the greatest initial demand continue to outperform on a size‐adjusted basis over longer time horizons.

Finally, we document a monotonic decline in the relationship between investor returns and underwriter reputation and market activities over longer return horizons. Simply put, investor returns over time are better explained by factors other than underwriter reputation and market activities. Although other researchers arrive at somewhat different conclusions, we suggest that this difference is most likely because other studies do not model underwriter activities as a sequential, integrated process. Rather, since underwriter activities are largely complete within one month of the offer date, we believe it is more plausible that subsequent economic conditions and business decisions by management determine future investor returns. Therefore, we do not recommend that issuers choose an underwriter on the basis of the misperception that, all else equal, investors will earn higher returns simply because a new issue is underwritten by a more prestigious investment bank.

The article is organized as follows. InSection II, we describe the empirical model of underwriter activities and investment bank reputation.Section IIIdescribes the sample selection procedure and provides summary statistics for the exogenous and endogenous variables used in the study.Section IVprovides the empirical results for the path analyses. We investigate the role of underwriter activities and reputation in the IPO process. We also examine how underwriter activities and reputation influence investor returns over increasingly longer time horizons.Section Vconcludes the article. Theappendixprovides a detailed discussion of the path analysis methodology.

fn.p: Loughran and Ritter (1999) use prospect theory to explain why issuers agree to price IPOs at a level where there is excess demand. In their model, partial price adjustments for high‐demand offers result in higher wealth levels for issuers than initially expected while simultaneously providing excess profits for investors.

Other explanations for underpricing exist. For example, Tinic (1988) argues that intentional underpricing reduces the probability of shareholder lawsuits when investment banks underwrite poor IPOs. Our analysis focuses only on explanations that consider both underpricing and rationing.

For other evidence on the lead underwriter’s important role throughout different periods of the IPO process, see Hanley (1993) for an analysis of the premarket period; Beatty and Ritter (1986), Carter and Manaster (1990), and Carter et al. (1998) for an analysis of underwriter reputation; and Hanley et al. (1993), Aggarwal (1998), and Ellis, Michaely, and O’Hara (2000) for an analysis of the aftermarket period. The results of a path analysis and a seemingly unrelated regression (SUR) or a full‐information, least‐generalized residual variance method (FI/LGRV) are qualitatively the same when the correlations among the errors in different equations are weakly related to each other. In this instance, both of these procedures can be viewed as a system ofNregression equations (see, e.g., Goldberger1964; Pedhauzer1997; and Pindyck and Rubinfeld1997). Path analysis is chosen over SUR because it provides a method for calculating the indirect effects of an independent variable in a multistage model. In addition, path analysis uses actual rather than predicted values for each independent variable in the estimation process. Since an underwriter can observe outcomes sequentially during the IPO process, it is appropriate to use actual rather than predicted values of the independent variables at each stage. Because the model is recursive, a standardized two‐stage least squares method is inappropriate. A more detailed discussion of path analysis can be found in Wright (1934,1954, and1960).
Ellis et al. (2000) find that most of an underwriter’s compensation in an IPO results from underwriting fees, not trading and inventory profits.

See Aggarwal (1998) for an extensive discussion and analysis of underwriter price stabilization practices. Note, however, that capital constraints may limit the ability of a small investment bank to underwrite a large issue if poor aftermarket price performance requires significant inventory accumulation.

sec.label: II.
sec.title: The Empirical Model
sec.p: A simple empirical model facilitates examination of the interrelated roles of underwriter reputation and market activities in the IPO market. We first investigate a model that hypothesizes a sequential relationship between premarket and aftermarket underwriter activities. The focus is on how premarket and aftermarket activities are related to each other and how these activities, in turn, are related to longer‐run investor returns. We then introduce underwriter reputation as an additional explanatory variable in order to focus on the separate roles of underwriter activities and the perceived quality of the underwriter during the IPO process.

The empirical findings reported in this study are based upon the estimation of a path analysis model. Path analysis is a system or chain of recursive ordinary least squares (OLS) regression equations that are theoretically linked. As in standard regression analysis, standardized coefficients are used to interpret the direct effects of independent variables on a dependent variable. Indirect effects, or the effects that might occur as a function of other variables in the system, may also be calculated from the standardized coefficients. Path analysis adds no statistical value to conventional regression analysis. The method does make explicit the rationale for a set of regression equations (direct effects) and provides a general procedure for calculating the indirect effects of an independent variable on a dependent variable in a multistage path model.6

Figure 1displays the hypothesized path diagram of underwriter premarket and aftermarket activities in the base case model. Causal paths run from left to right. Exogenous variables are at the left side of the figure, and endogenous variables are toward the middle and right. The arrows represent a one‐directional causal path in a path diagram, originating at the independent variable and pointing toward the dependent variable. Fig. 1.—
Path analysis diagram of the underwriter activities in IPO premarket, issue‐date, and aftermarket periods

The base case model includes three exogenous variables and five endogenous variables. The exogenous variables control for issue‐ and issuer‐specific factors that research indicates may influence the IPO underwriting process and investor returns (see, e.g., Logue1973; Logue and Lindvall1974).

The first exogenous factor that may influence underwriter activity and investor returns is offer size. Larger IPOs are often interpreted as entailing less risk because more mature firms usually float these IPOs. We use the natural logarithm of the expected issue proceeds (EXPRO) to control for the systematic influence of offer size. Expected issue proceeds are measured as the product of the expected offer size and expected offer price as indicated in the preliminary prospectus. Thus, offer size is measured prior to the measurement of underwriter activities or investor returns.

We also include as a control variable the natural logarithm of the issuer’s revenue in the fiscal year immediately prior to the IPO (REV). During the premarket period, investment banks commonly use a comparable companies methodology to establish the expected offer price of an IPO (see, e.g., Kim and Ritter1999). Revenue is often the most important operating performance metric in this valuation process, since other common performance benchmarks such as operating income and operating cash flow are frequently negative, especially for younger firms. Larger and more established revenue streams are more likely to produce more accurate estimates of firm value during the premarket period.

Finally, we control for differences in the ex ante risk of an issue through a measure of the preliminary offer price range (%DOLRNG). Research suggests that investor expectations of new issue pricing are related to the ex ante uncertainty about the value of the issuer (see, e.g., Beatty and Ritter1986). The costs of collecting and analyzing information are likely to be higher as uncertainty increases. The offer range is measured as the difference between the highest and the lowest anticipated values of the offer price indicated in the preliminary offer prospectus, divided by the lowest anticipated offer price.7
All else equal, lower‐risk IPOs would be characterized by larger offer size, higher revenue, and a narrower offer range.

Underwriters perform several important services during the IPO process on behalf of issuers. Prior to the issue date, the underwriter collects and disseminates information and certifies the quality of the issue and the issuer. On the issue date, the underwriter prices and distributes the new issue. After the issue date, the underwriter engages in aftermarket activities such as price stabilization, OAO exercise, and research coverage. The five endogenous variables in the base case path model provide performance measures of these various activities and are quantified as follows.

First, although the underwriter establishes a preliminary price and offer size, the final offer price and the exact number of shares to be sold are not determined until the day before issuance or sometimes the actual day of issuance. Since rationing and underpricing are the consequences of these final adjustments, we examine premarket changes by the underwriter as evidence of its marketing skills and expertise. Partial price adjustment (PPA) activities by underwriters are quantified by measuring revisions in expected offer prices during the premarket period. Changes in offer price are calculated as the difference between the actual offer price and the expected offer price, divided by the expected offer price.8

The consequence of final adjustments to the price and issue size is that issue‐date returns for investors are likely to be closely related to the premarket activities of the underwriter. The second endogenous variable, issue‐day underpricing (UNDPRI), is calculated as the difference between the offer date closing price and the offer price, divided by the offer price. This measure is the standard method of calculating initial date returns in the IPO literature.

We also examine two aftermarket underwriter activities. Since underwriters typically oversell an issue, the OAO provides an opportunity for the underwriter to cover the short position at a price equal to the offer price. Therefore, the OAO allows the underwriter to support demand for an issue without excessive exposure to price risk. We measure OAO exercise as the number of additional shares purchased by the underwriter under the OAO during the aftermarket period, divided by the number of registered shares sold in the offering (OAO). Underwriters can purchase up to 15% of the registered shares if the OAO is exercised. Thus, the variable ranges between 0% and 15%; higher values indicate greater use of the OAO by the underwriter.9

Note that the path diagram infigure 1identifies multiple influences on OAO exercise, as the arrows indicate. There are two important conditions that would cause an underwriter to exercise the OAO. The first occurs when the underwriter oversells underpriced shares. The second takes place when the underwriter oversells overpriced shares and the short position is not completely covered by purchases through a stabilizing bid or in the secondary market. We expect the first effect to be more influential, since the second is relevant only when there is limited secondary market volume.

The fourth endogenous variable, price stabilization (PRISTB), is an important but unobservable activity conducted by IPO underwriters. We define price stabilization to involve any activity by the underwriter designed to impede price declines of the new issue. Underwriters are not required to report their actual price stabilization activities. Therefore, the magnitude and duration of price stabilization are usually deduced by observing price and trading patterns during the aftermarket period.

Several proxies for measuring the impact of price stabilization have been proposed, including the width of bid‐ask spreads, estimates of Black‐Scholes put option prices, and the number of days until the secondary market price of the IPO first drops below the offer price. Our empirical tests use the latter measure, as proposed and implemented by Hanley, Kumar, and Seguin (1993) and Hanley, Lee, and Seguin (1996).10

For each IPO in the sample, we determine the number of days between the offer date and the first date the secondary market price drops below the offer price. Since this distribution is skewed, we create a discrete categorical variable based on a day‐count convention.

Issuers whose market prices decline below the issue price within 2 days of the offer date are put in the first category and are assigned a value of 1. Thus, low values of the categorical variable indicate that underwriters abandoned aftermarket support activities more quickly. If issuers experience price declines below the offer price within the next 28 days, we assume that underwriters were participating in extended price stabilization activities. These issues are put in the second category and are assigned a value of 2. Finally, higher values of the categorical variable indicate that price stabilization activities were not necessary. Issuers that did not experience price declines below the offer price within the first 30 days of trading are put in the third category and are assigned a value of 3.11

Finally, we examine the relationship between (1) premarket and aftermarket underwriter activities and (2) long‐run investor returns. The relationship is examined initially without consideration of the underwriter’s reputation. We then investigate whether the actual conduct of market activities and underwriter reputation are systematically related to longer‐run investor returns. Such a relationship would be of definite interest to issuers selecting an investment bank.

The base case model examines the marginal impact of underwriter activities on 1‐month size‐adjusted excess returns (EXRET). Following Ritter (1991) and Loughran and Ritter (1995), we calculate buy‐and‐hold returns for each offering from the first postissue closing price listed by the Center for Research in Security Prices (CRSP) to the appropriate anniversary date for several different holding‐period return horizons. We use the CRSP tapes to follow each issuing firm from its offer date until the earlier of (1) its delisting date, (2) the horizon period date, or (3) December 31, 1998.

Size‐adjusted excess returns are measured as the difference between the IPO buy‐and‐hold returns and the contemporaneous buy‐and‐hold returns on a portfolio of similarly sized non‐IPO firms. Excess returns at each holding‐period horizon are calculated as an equally weighted average of each individual stock’s excess returns. Thus, long‐run return performance is documented by calculating average excess returns for return horizons of 1, 3, 6, 12, and 36 months.12
The system of equations estimated in the base case path model is

fn.p: Path analysis requires that relationships among variables be linear and additive. Although none of our variables is hypothesized to have a moderating relationship with outcome (or dependent) variables, we test for moderation empirically, using standard diagnostic techniques (Cohen and Cohen1983). We find no significant or economically important moderating relationships, so we conclude that path analysis is an appropriate procedure for our sample.

The “dollar width” of the offer range is calculated as the difference between the highest and the lowest anticipated offer prices reported in the preliminary prospectus. The “percentage width” is the dollar width divided by the lowest anticipated offer price.
This is the same measure proposed by Hanley (1993) to detect revisions in the offer price during the premarket, or book‐building, period.
Muscarella, Peavy, and Vetsuypens (1992) provide empirical evidence on actual OAO exercise decisions by underwriters.

We use daily closing prices from the Center for Research in Security Prices (CRSP) to determine whether the market price dropped below the offer price. Therefore, our estimate of PRISTB depends on whether the closing price on any given day was above, equal to, or below the offer price.

Our analysis assumes that transaction prices below the offer price indicate the cessation of price stabilization activities. The offer price is the maximum allowable stabilizing bid under SEC Rule 10b‐7. To the extent that price stabilization occurs at prices below the offer price, our measurement of price stabilization works against identification of systematic factors that influence such activities. Since we cannot determine the actual date that stabilization ceases for each offer, we perform additional tests based on different assumptions about when stabilization ends. We repeat the analysis using Black‐Scholes put option prices as a proxy for the value of price stabilization and sorting issues into categories that depend only on whether there was any price stabilization activity. The results are largely unchanged under these alternative measures of price stabilization. These results are available from the authors upon request.

Although our returns use only size‐adjusted returns, we do not believe that our main results are sensitive to the matching‐method procedure that we follow. Loughran and Ritter (1995) show that, although the magnitude of the long‐run returns they calculate is somewhat sensitive to the matching method employed, their overall inferences about long‐run underperformance are not.

sec.label: III.
sec.title: Sample Selection and Data Description
sec.p: The data for our study are obtained from several sources. We initially identified a list of 3,753 offerings classified as IPOs by theSecurities Data Corporation New Issues Databasefrom January 1988 through December 1995. We eliminate 1,492 issuers with pro forma market capitalization below $50 million, as well as 1,132 issues with offer prices of less than $8 per share. This eliminates small, risky, illiquid issues from the sample.13

We also exclude IPOs by financial institutions (864 issues), limited partnerships (19 issues), and unit offerings (85 issues). With some overlap among these nonexclusive constraints, 1,567 IPOs remain. We eliminate an additional 67 issues because the issuer firms do not have stock return information available on the CRSP tape. Finally, since we require accurate information on OAO exercise, an additional 25 IPOs are eliminated because we could not verify that the Securities Data Corporation (SDC) information for these issues is correct. Our final sample consists of 1,475 IPOs.14

Table 1provides summary issue and issuer descriptive statistics for the full sample, as well as a breakdown by relation of final offer price to preliminary offer range. Offer price revisions are one of the most important premarket activities conducted by IPO underwriters. This presentation facilitates a univariate examination of the descriptive statistics of other elements in the IPO underwriting process in relation to revisions in the offer price. Table 1

Note.—Median values are in parentheses. Dollar width of offer range is the difference between the highest and lowest anticipated values of the offer price as quoted in the preliminary prospectus. Percentage width of offer range is the dollar width of the offer range divided by the lowest anticipated value of the offer price as quoted in the preliminary prospectus. Expected offer price is the sum of the highest and lowest anticipated values of the offer price as quoted in the preliminary prospectus, divided by two. Percentage change in shares offered is calculated as the actual number of shares offered (excluding the exercise of the overallotment option) minus the number of shares quoted in the preliminary prospectus, divided by the number of shares quoted in the preliminary prospectus. Total proceeds is the number of shares sold (excluding the exercise of the overallotment option) multiplied by the actual offer price. Pro forma market capitalization of issuer is equal to the total number of shares outstanding after issue multiplied by the offer price. Carter‐Manaster underwriter quality ranking is a discrete underwriter reputation variable between 0 and 9, where 9 is the most prestigious underwriter and 0 is the least prestigious underwriter. Offer date return is the percentage increase or decrease from the offering price to the first available closing price. One‐month raw returns are geometrically compounded buy‐and‐hold returns on the stock over the first month of trading excluding the initial date return. One‐month size‐adjusted returns are geometrically compounded returns on the stock minus geometrically compounded returns on the corresponding CRSP market capitalization decile portfolio. OAO exercise is the number of additional shares issued by the underwriter through exercise of the OAO divided by the actual number of registered shares offered. Price stabilization is a three‐level categorical variable based on the number of days between the offer date and the first date that the secondary market price drops below the offer price. Higher values indicate that price stabilization activities were not necessary, and lower values indicate that underwriters abandoned their aftermarket support activities more quickly.

Column 2 reports descriptive statistics for the 312 issuers whose final offer price was less than the lowest price reported in the preliminary offer prospectus (21.2% of overall sample). Column 3 reports descriptive statistics for the 712 issuers whose final offer price was within the offer price range reported in the preliminary offer prospectus (48.3%). Column 4 reports descriptive statistics for the 451 issuers whose final offer price exceeded the highest price reported in the preliminary offer prospectus (30.6%). Pairwise significance tests of differences between issue and issuer characteristics are provided for these three IPO subsamples using the Wilcoxon rank‐sum test.15

Table 1provides average and median values of the preceding year’s revenue for the issuing firm, the expected offer price, the actual offer price, the percentage change in the number of shares offered, and the total proceeds of the offering (excluding the exercise of the overallotment option). Issuers revising offer prices below the offer range have significantly higher revenues, higher expected offer prices, and lower actual offer prices than either issuers within the offer range or issuers revising the offer price above the offer range. Apparently, larger firms establish higher expected offer prices but then subsequently reduce the price on the offer date.

In addition, changes in offer prices are often accompanied by changes in the number of shares offered. Issuers revising offer prices below the offer range reduce the number of shares actually sold, while issuers priced within and above the offer range increase the number of shares sold. Reductions in offer prices are often accompanied by reductions in the number of shares sold, thereby lowering the actual proceeds received by the issuer. Conversely, increases in offer prices are usually accompanied by increases in the number of shares sold, although excess demand remains high even at this adjusted level.16

Overall, these initial descriptive statistics indicate a substantial revision in the terms of the offering for issues whose final offer price is either above or below the offer range. Issuers with final offer prices above the offer range receive total offer proceeds that are significantly higher than issuers whose final offer price is less than the offer range, but significantly lower total offer proceeds than the issuers whose price is within the offer range. Note, however, that issuers whose final offer price is higher than the offer range obtain these proceeds by selling the lowest number of shares in the IPO. This suggests that control considerations may play an important role in the rationing equilibrium.

Table 1also provides average Carter‐Manaster underwriter quality rankings for the lead investment banks in our sample IPOs. Lead underwriters for each IPO are identified from the SDC database, and Carter‐Manaster underwriter reputation measures come from Carter et al. (1998). Overall, average Carter‐Manaster quality rankings are significantly higher for issues priced above and below the expected offer range. Higher‐quality investment banks are associated with significant upward and downward price revisions. This suggests that premarket underwriter activities are likely to have an important effect on issue‐date returns and therefore on the aftermarket underwriting activities of the investment banks.

Evidence of differences in offer date and short‐run aftermarket returns across issuer subsamples is also provided intable 1. Offer date returns are large and positive across all three subsamples. Confirming results reported in many other studies, IPOs are significantly underpriced on average. The degree of the underpricing is related to the preissue underwriting activities of the investment banks. Issues whose final prices are adjusted above the preliminary offer range experience the greatest degree of underpricing. These issues are also more likely to increase the number of shares issued. This is the partial price adjustment phenomenon documented by Hanley (1993), in which shares in an offering are rationed and prices adjust only partially to new information.

Issues revising the offer price above the offer range experience the best raw and size‐adjusted excess rates of return during the month after the issue date. This indicates that the adjustment process for the underpricing of high‐demand issues is not resolved immediately, perhaps because of the aftermarket underwriting activities of the investment banks. Investment banks affect the supply of shares and market prices during the month after the offer date. Issue liquidity may also be a factor, since firms often sell only a relatively small volume of their shares during an IPO.

Measures of two important aftermarket underwriting activities are exercise of the OAO and price stabilization activities. Exercise of the OAO is significantly higher for issuers revising the offer price above the offer range than for either of the other two issuer subsamples, indicating that high‐demand issues experience not only the greatest amount of underpricing but also the largest aftermarket share supply adjustment. Investment banks use the OAO to cover the short position established on the offer date to meet the excess investor demand for the issue.

Table 2presents information on OAO use sorted by premarket price adjustment activities. For the full sample, the OAO is fully exercised in 49% (722/1,475) of the IPOs. The table also confirms that partial price adjustments during the premarket period are related to OAO exercise decisions during the aftermarket period. The OAO is fully exercised for only 23% (71/312) of the IPOs with final offer prices below the offer range. It is fully exercised for 47% (333/712) and 70% (318/451) of the IPOs priced within and above the offer range, however. Table 2

The results also hint that, while underwriters exercise OAO to cover short positions in underpriced IPOs, other factors also influence their use. That is, price adjustments during the premarket period are not the sole determinant of the OAO exercise decision. For example, in some cases, underwriters may choose to reward investors with larger allocations of shares that are less underpriced rather than smaller allocations of shares that are more underpriced.

The intensity of price stabilization activities is deduced from the level of PRISTB. A high value indicates no price stabilization, while a low value indicates price stabilization activities that are abandoned relatively quickly. An intermediate value can be interpreted to indicate a more sustained period of price stabilization activities. The premarket price adjustment process is not complete for issuers that revise their offer prices below the offer range. Investment banks price‐stabilize these low‐demand issues but also abandon these activities more quickly than the other two issuer subsample groups.

Overall, the subsample data comparisons described in tables1and2suggest that differences in issue and issuer characteristics are related to premarket pricing adjustments. These adjustments, in turn, appear to be related to investor returns and aftermarket underwriter activities. In addition, differences in investment bank reputation appear to play a role.

fn.p: Several other recent studies use the $8 minimum, primarily to reduce the influence of microcap stocks (see, e.g., Krigman, Shaw, and Womack1999; Loughran and Ritter1999). We also find that these issues are less likely to have the underwriter reputation and market activities information that we require for our study.

Ellis et al. (2000) find that SDC often misreports actual OAO exercise. We verify SDC’s information for our sample by obtaining information about OAO exercise from the underwriter, the issuing firm, and 10Q and 10K filings. We also identify a substantial number of issues for which SDC misreported the OAO data.

Hanley (1993) reports that 27% of her sample of 1,430 IPOs from January 1983 through September 1987 reduced the final offer price below the offer range; 63% went public within the offer range; and 10% increased the final offer price above the offer range. For our sample, more new issues had final offer prices above the preliminary offer range, and fewer new issues had final offer prices below. This comparison suggests that there may have been a significant change in the provision of premarket underwriter activities in the 1990s. Additional evidence in support of this hypothesis is provided in Beatty and Welch (1996).

Our results do not distinguish between primary and secondary shares in the IPO. We are not aware of any theory that predicts a relationship between the origin of the shares offered and the role of underwriter reputation and underwriting activities. It would be interesting to investigate whether such a relationship exists.

sec.label: A.
sec.title: What Is the Role of Underwriter Market Activities in the IPO Process?
sec.p:
Table 3presents the results of the base case path analysis model. This version of the model investigates the role of underwriter market activities in the IPO process, independent of the identity (and therefore reputation) of the underwriter. The table provides the direct effects (DE) and indirect effects (IE) for each path in the theoretical model. Table 3

The dependent variables are partial price adjustment (PPA), underpricing (UNDPRI), overallotment option exercise (OAO), price stabilization (PRISTB), and 1‐month excess return (EXRET) for the five paths estimated in the base case model. PPA is calculated as the difference between the actual offer price and the expected offer price, divided by the expected offer price. UNDPRI is calculated as the difference between the offer date closing price and the offer price, divided by the offer price. OAO is calculated as the number of additional shares purchased by the underwriter through the overallotment option divided by the number of registered shares sold in the offering. PRISTB is a discrete variable that depends on the first time the secondary market price drops below the offer price. PRISTB equals 3 if the market price does not decline below the offer price within 30 days of the offer date, 2 if the market price drops below the offer price at least 3 days after the offer date, and 1 if the market price drops below the offer price less than 3 days after the offer date. EXRET is calculated as a size‐adjusted, 1‐month excess return measured as the difference between the IPO buy‐and‐hold return and the contemporaneous buy‐and‐hold return on a portfolio of similarly sized non‐IPO firms. The independent variables for the PPA path include the natural logarithm of the expected issue proceeds (EXPRO); the difference between the highest and lowest anticipated offer price divided by the lowest anticipated offer price (%DOLRNG); and the natural logarithm of the issuer’s revenue (REV). The independent variables for the UNDPRI path include EXPRO, %DOLRNG, REV, and PPA. The independent variables for the OAO path include EXPRO, %DOLRNG, REV, PPA, UNDPRI, and PRISTB. The independent variables for the PRISTB path include EXPRO, %DOLRNG, REV, PPA, and UNDPRI. The independent variables for EXRET include PPA, UNDPRI, OAO, and PRISTB. Standardized path coefficients are reported. DE indicates a direct effect, and IE indicates an indirect effect.

TheR 2values suggest that the model explains a significant proportion of the variability in each dependent variable. The significance levels of the path coefficients indicate that the data largely support the model predictions of significant causal effects between the variables.

The first column indicates that two issue‐specific characteristics are significant systematic determinants of premarket price adjustments. Offer prices are more likely to be reduced as offer size increases and to be adjusted upward as issue risk increases. This indicates that underwriters generally overestimate investor demand for larger issues and underestimate investor demand for risky issues. Price adjustments during the premarket period compensate for the additional discount (for issue size) and premium (for uncertainty) required by investors.

Table 1indicates that expected offer prices for issues with final offer prices below the preliminary range are significantly higher than the expected offer prices for the other two categories. The path analysis indicates that aggressive preliminary offer pricing by underwriters appears to be a mistake. When underwriters try to raise more capital than investors are willing to provide, they end up reducing both the offer price and the number of shares. The results also indicate that firms with larger revenue bases are more likely to adjust their offer prices downward, although the path coefficient is not significantly related to changes in the final offer price.

TheR 2value of 0.07 for partial price adjustment indicates that, while the three exogenous issue and issuer characteristics have some predictive power regarding new issue price adjustments, there are additional important factors that are omitted. This result is consistent with the Benveniste and Spindt (1989) model, in that investors’ private information about their true demand for new issues is an important factor in the book‐building process. We would not expect to be able to predict partial price adjustments accurately on the basis of only observable issue and issuer characteristics. The role of the investment bank is to discover this information through its premarket solicitation of investor demand.

The more important result is that IPOs whose issue prices are raised above the expected offer prices are more underpriced. The relationship between the preliminary offer price range and the actual offer price is the most significant determinant of issue‐date returns. Underpricing is more likely for issues that raise their offer prices above the expected offer price during the premarket period. While this can be interpreted as evidence that issuers leave a considerable amount of value “on the table” for new investors, it is also consistent with the effective use of rationing as a selling mechanism for these IPOs. The fact that offer size is smallest for issuers with the greatest premarket price adjustments suggests that one potential benefit of the rationing strategy may be the retention of greater control by the pre‐IPO owners.

The positive relationship between issue‐date underpricing and OAO exercise is not surprising, given the common practice of overselling new issues. If underwriters reward investors for truthful revelation of demand information (in the form of larger share allocations), the OAO allows the investment bank to obtain additional shares at the offer price. This suggests that issuing firms ultimately bear the cost of acquiring true investor demand information. What is surprising is that underpricing is neither the sole nor the most important determinant of OAO exercise.

The results also indicate that small issues are more likely to experience greater OAO exercise, while issues that experience upward revisions in the offer price and issues that are not price‐stabilized are more likely to have more OAO exercise. The more intensive use of the OAO for IPOs for which good information is revealed by investors during the premarket period is consistent with an increase in share allocation as partial compensation for truth telling. Interestingly, even though issues whose prices have been adjusted upward are more likely to have their issue sizes adjusted upward during the premarket period, they also have the greatest aftermarket adjustment of issue size.

One explanation for this result is that the underwriter can exercise the OAO when it has oversold a new issue by an amount sufficient to reduce the issue price discount. In this case, we would expect to observe the OAO used in different issue conditions.

One explanation for this result is that price stabilization activities may not provide a sufficient number of shares for the investment bank to cover a short position established in the offering. For these issues, OAO exercise may be a more efficient way to cover the remaining short position.

Price stabilization activities are more likely for large offers, while large revenue issuers and underpriced issues are less likely to experience price stabilization activities. These results are consistent with the Benveniste et al. (1996) prediction that underpricing and price stabilization activities are substitutes.

Both aftermarket underwriter activities are significantly related to 1‐month excess returns. These activities affect secondary market prices as well as the volume of shares outstanding during this aftermarket period. Exercise of OAO is positively and significantly related to 1‐month excess returns. Issues with high OAO exercise have significantly greater 1‐month excess returns. Not surprisingly, perhaps, issues that are not price‐stabilized experience the greatest 1‐month excess returns. In addition, among issues that are price‐stabilized, those issues with extended periods of price stabilization experience greater 1‐month excess returns than issues for which price stabilization activities are abandoned quickly. Finally, there is no evidence that premarket underwriter activities directly influence 1‐month excess returns.

sec.label: B.
sec.title: What Is the Role of Underwriter Reputation in the IPO Process?
sec.p: Several researchers have examined the effects of underwriter reputation on the initial performance of IPOs (see, e.g., Logue1973; Logue and Lindvall1974; Beatty and Ritter1986; and Carter et al.1998). Carter et al. (1998) also find that long‐run underperformance is less severe for IPOs associated with more prestigious underwriters.17

Table 4extends the results of the base case analysis by introducing a measure of underwriter quality as an exogenous variable. The Carter‐Manaster measures are hypothesized to have a direct influence on each endogenous variable in the model. Standardized path coefficients andR 2values for the endogenous variables are reported. Table 4

\documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $p< .001$ \end{document} .

The finding also supports the hypothesis that higher‐quality investment banks have more informed investors. This gives underwriters access to better information, which in turn allows them to adjust prices prior to issue. In either case, the results suggest that higher‐quality investment banks are more likely than lower‐quality investment banks to increase offer prices on the basis of premarket information collection.

Since the conduct of premarket underwriter activities is related to the quality of the investment bank, issuers concerned about price adjustments prior to the offer date should consider hiring higher‐quality investment banks. Our results indicate that high‐quality underwriters appear to be better at obtaining similar amounts of capital through higher prices and/or the sale of fewer shares. This suggests that they may be more adept at solving information problems and/or preserving inside control.

Other significant partial price adjustment results from the base case model are unchanged, suggesting that the exogenous issue and issuer characteristics are relatively robust indicators of partial price adjustment.

At the same time, lower‐quality investment banks underwrite IPOs that are less likely to require price stabilization activities. For issues that require price stabilization activities, higher‐quality investment banks abandon price stabilization activities more quickly than lower‐quality investment banks do. Thus, conditional on the need for price stabilization activities, a lower‐quality investment bank may use the opportunity to provide more extensive price stabilization as a way to enhance its future reputation.

The Carter‐Manaster quality‐ranking variable also has a positive indirect effect on price stabilization through partial price adjustment and underpricing activities. Higher‐quality banks tend to adjust offer prices during the premarket period more frequently and to underprice more. This may simply reflect the fact that issues for which greater‐than‐expected demand has been revealed are more difficult to price than more standard IPOs. In addition, more of these premarket and issue‐date activities appear to be related to IPOs for which price stabilization activities were not necessary.

Benveniste et al. (1996) suggest that investment bank quality is a good proxy for the ability to commit credibly to aftermarket underwriting activities. Credible commitments are especially important for price stabilization activities in the aftermarket period. The fact that the Carter‐Manaster quality ranking is significantly related to the price stabilization activity measure but insignificantly related to OAO exercise is consistent with this view. Our finding that lower‐quality investment banks maintain the necessary price stabilization activities for longer periods than higher‐quality investment banks is also consistent with this view.

All other variables retain their significance levels as in the base case model, although issue size declines somewhat in significance (from the .001 to the .01 level), and partial price adjustment increases in significance (from .05 to .01).

Finally,table 4indicates that investment bank quality rankings, after controlling for premarket, issue‐date, and aftermarket underwriting activities, have no independent effect on 1‐month excess returns. Overall model fit is unaffected by introduction of the Carter‐Manaster quality ranking, and the other explanatory variables retain their signs and significance levels. This indicates that it is not investment bank reputation per se that influences investor returns over longer return horizons but, rather, the actual activities of the underwriters.

To put it another way, high‐quality investment banks distinguish themselves by conducting market activities differently and presumably better than their less prestigious counterparts. This difference is especially important during the premarket period. Even if less prestigious investment banks choose to emulate the behavior of a prestigious bank, it would take a long time for them to achieve the credibility of the well‐capitalized and established ones.

fn.p: Tinic (1988) presents an argument that suggests underwriter quality is endogenous. We do not directly identify or examine factors that explain the cross‐sectional variation in underwriter reputation, but it would be worthwhile to analyze the factors that systematically contribute to underwriter reputation.

sec.label: C.
sec.title: The Role of Underwriter Reputation and Market Activities over Longer‐Run Return Horizons
sec.p:
Evidence on the impact of investment bank quality and underwriter activities on investor returns over longer time horizons is presented in tables5and6. Hanley (1993) examines the long‐run performance of IPOs according to revisions in offer prices to see whether issues with final offer prices above the offer range have greater price declines than issues within or below the offer range. Her analysis is motivated by Ritter’s (1991) evidence that firms with high initial returns tend to have the worst aftermarket performance. Ritter attributes his findings to potential overreaction in the market for IPOs. The evidence in Hanley (1993) suggests that there is an insignificant relation between revisions in the offer price and long‐run price performance. Table 5

Table 5presents returns over different time horizons for IPOs with final offer prices below, within, and above the preliminary offer range. Raw (unadjusted) and size‐adjusted buy‐and‐hold returns are presented for 1‐, 3‐, 6‐, 12‐, and 36‐month holding periods.

Initial public offerings experience positive raw return performance over each holding period. The same is true when IPOs are sorted by the relation of the issue price to the offer range quoted in the preliminary prospectus. Over shorter time horizons, raw returns are higher for issues whose final offer prices are above the preliminary offer range. Over longer time horizons, however, raw returns are higher for issues whose final offer prices are below the preliminary offer range.

The size‐adjusted return results indicate that IPOs earn positive excess returns relative to similarly sized non‐IPO firms for the first year but significantly underperform thereafter. Size‐adjusted return performance is also related to the relative final offer price and preliminary offer range. Beyond 1 year, issues whose final offer prices are above the preliminary offer range perform relatively poorly. Issues whose final offer prices are below the preliminary offer range perform the best, and they slightly outperform on a size‐adjusted basis. The short‐term results are the opposite of the long‐term results.

Table 6presents direct and indirect effects for five separate path models over different return horizons. These path analysis results over different return horizons indicate the extent to which underwriter reputation and market activities are related to investors’ longer‐run excess returns. Since the only difference in model results occurs with regard to the time period during which excess returns are measured, we do not present the standardized path coefficients for partial price adjustment, underpricing, OAO exercise, or price stabilization. (The coefficients for each of these paths would be the same as those presented intable 4.)18

Table 6shows that the overall explanatory power of the path model declines monotonically over longer time horizons. The modelR 2declines from 0.08 for the 3‐month excess return model to 0.02 for the 36‐month excess return model. Over shorter time horizons, the investment banks perform underwriting services more likely to influence investor returns. For example, investment banks influence supply and demand in the premarket and aftermarket through partial price adjustments, OAO exercise, and price stabilization decisions. At least for short periods of time, these activities are expected to influence returns. Because regulations require that these activities cease soon after the IPO is completed, other factors presumably affect investor returns over longer time periods.

Table 6provides several other results worth noting. First, investment bank quality has very little direct influence on investor returns during any time horizon examined. Generally, Carter‐Manaster quality rankings are positive but insignificantly related to long‐run excess returns. The only exception is that the Carter‐Manaster quality ranking is marginally significant at the .05 level in the 6‐month excess return model. The indirect effect of the Carter‐Manaster quality ranking on excess returns is also small (ranging between −.03 and −.01).

The impact of the quality of an investment bank on longer‐run investor returns occurs through its supply and demand activities during the premarket and aftermarket periods. Premarket underwriting activities have only a marginal impact on investor returns over longer time horizons. There is a negative and significant relation (.05 level) between partial price adjustments and the 3‐ and 6‐month excess returns, indicating that issues whose prices are adjusted upward from the expected offer price perform more poorly than other IPOs over these time horizons. For longer time periods of 12 and 36 months, the coefficient retains the negative sign but is insignificant. This suggests that, contrary to Ritter (1991), issues with final offer prices above the offer range do not generally experience greater 36‐month price declines than issues within or below the offer range.

Issue‐date returns (i.e., underpricing) have very little predictive power for investor returns for periods beyond 3 months. Underpricing is negative but insignificantly related to long‐run excess returns. We suggest that the aftermarket underwriting activities of investment banks potentially interfere, at least for short time periods, with the unconstrained equilibrium of supply and demand. Once that equilibrium is established (and explicit underwriter interference with that activity must cease within 30 days of issue), investor returns are progressively less influenced. Indirect effects of underpricing on long‐run returns through OAO price stabilization activities continue for the first year and then have less of an impact for longer return horizons (IE declines from 0.15 in the 3‐month excess return model to 0.07 in the 36‐month excess return model).

Aftermarket underwriter activities appear to have the strongest relationship with investor returns over long‐run return horizons. Price stabilization activities are particularly important for 3‐, 6‐, and 12‐month return horizons, while OAO exercise becomes more important over the 36‐month time period. Standardized path coefficients are significant and positive for both aftermarket underwriter activities, indicating that issues with the greatest OAO exercise and the smallest amount of price stabilization perform best over these longer‐run horizons.

fn.p: To be consistent with prior research, we do not include raw returns as a dependent variable in any of the path models reported.

sec.label: V.
sec.title: Summary and Conclusion
sec.p: This research advances our knowledge of the IPO process in several ways. First, it clarifies the significant role of the underwriter and illustrates how coordinated activities by an investment bank facilitate cost‐efficient initial public offerings. Some models of IPO pricing view underwriters as passive participants in the process; Allen and Faulhaber (1989) and Rock (1986) are examples. Our results suggest that these analyses provide an incomplete picture of the IPO underwriting process. A representation of the IPO market as comprising issuers and investors while ignoring the strategic pricing and share allocation roles of the underwriter omits a crucial component of the process.

Second, we are the first to consider the set of actions that investment banks undertake as an integrated process, explicitly recognizing the interdependencies among premarket, issue‐date, and aftermarket underwriter activities. Our analysis clarifies the relationship between the various underwriter activities and the returns that investors earn during different periods after the offering. It also shows that investment bank reputation has implications for both underwriter activities during the underwriting process and investor returns. An important finding is that the principal influence of underwriter reputation on investor returns is not direct, but rather indirect, through their conduct of premarket underwriting activities. We also find that underwriter reputation facilitates the conduct of premarket underwriting activities. Since the conduct of premarket underwriter activities is related to the quality of the investment bank, issuers concerned about price adjustments prior to the offer date should consider hiring higher‐quality investment banks.

Finally, our results differ from the conclusions reported in other studies, but we suggest that our principal empirical findings are not particularly surprising. We attribute the differences to the fact that other empirical studies tend to focus only on particular activities conducted by investment banks during the IPO underwriting process. Our study provides a more comprehensive analysis of the full set of premarket, issue‐date, and aftermarket activities.

Underwriter reputation and market activities are elements in a sequential, integrated process that investment banks conduct on behalf of issuers. Therefore, proper inferences about the IPO underwriting process can be drawn only if these relationships are fully rather than partially considered.

app.label: Appendix A
app.title: Path Analysis Models
app.p: Path analysis models a system of linear relationships, similar in spirit to a full‐information, least‐generalized residual variance method (FI/LGRV). The variables of the system are classified into two types: exogenous and endogenous. An exogenous or predetermined variable is affected only by variables outside the causal model. Endogenous variables, also known as jointly dependent variables, are affected by other variables in the model. The overall model constitutes a set of structures, or equations, that connect the variables in a specific, hypothesized way. An important advantage of the method is that it explicitly incorporates the a priori knowledge of the sequential processes under investigation.

TheR 2reflects the extent to which the independent variables in the model account for variability in the dependent variables. Standardized path coefficients (similar to standardized regression coefficients) rather than raw path coefficients are reported so that all variables are in the same unit of measurement (i.e., all variables have a standard deviation of 1.00). This approach allows comparisons of relative size to ascertain which independent variable has the greatest effect on the dependent variables.
